We have adopted this program in order to implelemnt 40 C.F.R. 68, the federal requirements regulating Risk Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals.



This Program will prevent the occurance of, or minimize the consequences of, catastropic releases by stating our policies and procedures for the management of process hazards in start-up, operation, inspection, maintenance and the other matters addressed in the federal standard.



Our Program calls for maximum employee participation and includes all elements of the employee participation provisions of the standard. We shall, as a minimum: (1) consult with employees and their representatives on the conduct and development of the process hazard review and other elements of the risk management plan, and (2) provide to our employees and their representatives access to the process hazard review and all other information required to be developed under that standard.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The City of Conroe believes that preventative maintenance is the key to minimizing the potential for accidental releases. Standard Operating Procedures (SOP's) have been reviewed and revised to enable the employees to perform their work in a safe and efficient manner.

The city of Conroe has taken steps to educate and inform the operators, suprvisors, and maintenance crews in the appropiate response to an accidental release. The training includes classroom training and operating procedures on the proper response to emergency situations.



Stationary Source and Regulated Substances



The Southwest Wastewater Treatment Plant utilizes chlorine for disinfection and sulfur dioxide for dechlorination of the treated wastewater. The maximum inventory and theshold quantities for these chemicals are shown below. All chlorine and sulfur dioxide containers are stored and utilized within separate buildings. The builings will act as passive mitigation in the event of a release.

Offsite Consequence Analysis



The offsite consequence analysis includes a worst-case release scenario and an alternative scenario as defined in 40 C.F.R. 68. A dense-gas model (SLAB) was used to determine endpoint distances for both scenarios. A dense-gas model is required since both chlorine and sulfur dioxide are heavier than air. The model's input parameters are summaried in the table below.

Accidental Release Prevention Program



The City of Conroe has implemented a General Accidental Release Prevention Program to minimize releases. This Program includes: safety information on the covered chemicals, hazard reviews, operation and maintenance procedures, training, compliance audits, incident investigations, and emergency response procedures.



Five-year Accident History



In the past 5 years, there have not been any accidental releases from the process that have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsi

te deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place,property damage, or environmental damage.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



The City of Conroe has implemented a Risk Management Plan (RMP) that meets or exceeds the requirements of 40 CFR 68. It is Conroe's philosophy to continually improve the safe working conditions of its employees to minimize accidents and reduce the potential for either an on-site or off-site release. With this in mind, Conroe has incorporated many of the RMP elements into other areas of the process not covered under 40 CFR 68 to improve the overall safety of the plant.
